\u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;un-proyecto-para-crecer-con-garantias\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Un proyecto para “crecer con garantías”\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;De cara al futuro próximo, Forus aspira, según explica Miguel Callejo Gonzalo, director de Infraestructura, Comunicaciones y Seguridad en Forus, a estandarizar los centros que tiene la empresa a nivel internacional; mejorar la eficiencia operativa y el TCO; disponer de visibilidad y monitorización en tiempo real para anticiparse a incidencias y reducir MTTR; y acelerar la apertura de nuevos centros con despliegues zero touch.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Gracias al acuerdo con la operadora, añade, Forus ahora contará con “una base tecnológica común para operaciones \u0026lt;em\u0026gt;data driven\u0026lt;/em\u0026gt; (telemetría avanzada, analítica de wifi para invitados, segmentación de servicios…), nuevos casos de uso (IoT, control de aforos, medios de pago en movilidad) y mejoras de experiencia para empleados y usuarios”. Además, suma, “facilita la automatización y la escala internacional sin incrementar la complejidad”.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;En definitiva, según el equipo de TI de Forus, gracias al nuevo proyecto, la compañía da “un paso decisivo en su hoja de ruta internacional: una plataforma común, segura y escalable para 60 centros en ES/IT/PT”. Durante los próximos cinco años, avanza Callejo, el grupo reforzará la excelencia operativa y la experiencia de sus usuarios, “con la ambición de crecer con garantías y medir cada avance”.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“Entendemos la tecnología como un habilitador del servicio: esta transformación nos ofrece una red única y confiable para acompañar nuestro crecimiento y ofrecer una experiencia mejor a cada usuario, hoy y en los próximos años”, concluye el director de Infraestructura, Comunicaciones y Seguridad en Forus.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; id=\u0026quot;remove_no_follow\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;grid grid--cols-10@md grid--cols-8@lg article-column\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;col-12 col-10@md col-6@lg col-start-3@lg\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;article-column__content\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;section class=\u0026quot;wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;container\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/section\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;I’ve spent the last two decades building AI systems in environments where “mostly right” isn’t good enough — online security, search, financial risk, supply chains and now product development in CPG.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Across all of it, the pattern is consistent:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Most teams don’t need more AI-generated content. They need better decisions — faster, more consistent and safely repeatable under real constraints.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;That’s the difference between an AI demo and an AI product that changes how an industry operates.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;A decision product is not a chatbot bolted onto a workflow. It’s a system that takes messy reality — partial data, conflicting priorities, human heuristics, business constraints — and produces actionable choices with:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Explicit guardrails and constraints (what must be true)\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Measurable outcomes and feedback loops (did it work?)\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Auditability (“why this decision, with what evidence”)\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Clear escalation boundaries (what the system can do vs. what requires approval)\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;To make this practical across non-tech industries — manufacturing, insurance, healthcare ops, retail, supply chain, CPG — I use what I call the Decision Product Operating Model (DPOM): a mode-based way to choose autonomy, capture SME expertise and scale decision quality without taking on unnecessary risk.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;step-1-choose-the-mode-before-you-choose-the-model\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Step 1: Choose the mode before you choose the model\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;When teams say “we’re building agents,” I pull them back to the first-order product decision:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;What mode are you shipping? Autonomy is a product decision before it’s a technical decision.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h3 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;mode-1-manual-traditional\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Mode 1: Manual / Traditional\u0026lt;/h3\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Humans do the thinking. The product coordinates: data entry, approvals, reporting, dashboards.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Manual is often correct for:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;High-stakes, low-frequency decisions\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Unclear policies (“we’ll know it when we see it”)\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Low reversibility (you can’t undo the action without damage)\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Manual breaks down when decision frequency rises — or when outcomes depend on a few people who carry the playbook in their heads.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h3 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;mode-2-assistive-copilot\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Mode 2: Assistive (Copilot)\u0026lt;/h3\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The system proposes options, highlights trade-offs, drafts recommendations and speeds up expert work.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;This is where most AI products land — and it can be valuable. But it’s also where many teams accidentally ship persuasive noise.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The failure mode is predictable: users either over-rely on the system or ignore it entirely. That “use/misuse/disuse/abuse” pattern has been studied for decades in human-automation systems and shows up quickly \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1518/001872097778543886\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;when automation isn’t designed for the actual operating context\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;A real copilot doesn’t just generate text. It narrows the decision space using real constraints, communicates uncertainty honestly and makes correction cheap.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h3 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;mode-3-agentic-autopilot\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Mode 3: Agentic (Autopilot)\u0026lt;/h3\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The system takes actions: triggers workflows, executes changes, runs checks, routes exceptions — within policy.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Agentic creates a compounding advantage when decisions are:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Frequent\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Time-sensitive\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Reversible\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Governed by clear rules and thresholds\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;But agentic is not a branding choice. It’s an operational contract. If the system acts, you need permissions, monitoring, rollback and accountability.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;step-2-treat-sme-expertise-as-a-product-asset-not-feedback\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Step 2: Treat SME expertise as a product asset, not “feedback”\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Here’s what separates companies that “use AI” from companies that win with AI in non-tech industries:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The model is rarely the moat.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The moat is operationalized expertise.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Every successful decision product I’ve built — or watched succeed — treats SME knowledge as a first-class product artifact, not a collection of tribal tips.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;SMEs supply the policy layer that makes decisions safe and repeatable:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Hard constraints:\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; “Never exceed X.” “Must meet Y spec.”\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Soft preferences:\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; “Prefer A unless B.”\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Escalation triggers:\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; “If variance \u0026amp;gt; threshold, route to QA.”\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Exception playbooks:\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; “When supplier changes, run these checks.”\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Acceptance tests:\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; “This is what ‘good’ looks like.”\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Rollback:\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; “If this goes wrong, here’s how we unwind it safely.”\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;This is where decision products are born: not in prompting, but in translating judgment into policy, guardrails and measurable tests.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;In domains like supply chain or CPG R\u0026amp;amp;D, the decision isn’t a neat closed-form optimization problem. It’s a trade-off across constraints — cost, quality, service levels, regulatory boundaries, sensory performance, variability, supply risk — under imperfect data. If constraints aren’t explicit, the product can’t be trusted. If it can’t be trusted, it won’t be used. And if it isn’t used consistently, it can’t improve.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;step-3-let-user-expertise-determine-the-default-experience\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Step 3: Let user expertise determine the default experience\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;One of the biggest mistakes I see is designing one “AI experience” for everyone.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;In non-tech industries, teams are mixed: a few deep SMEs, many capable operators and leadership demanding speed. Your product must scale expertise without pretending everyone is an expert — or that the AI is.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h3 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;novices-need-a-translated-mental-model\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Novices need a translated mental model\u0026lt;/h3\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Novices don’t need more features. They need the product to translate intent into structure.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;In many industries, people don’t naturally talk in “constraints,” “objectives,” and “trade-offs.” They talk in outcomes, rules of thumb and war stories. Great products turn that into:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Guided flows that translate intent into constraints\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;explanations that show trade-offs (not just recommendations)\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Correction loops that are fast and low-friction\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h3 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;experts-need-control-not-generic-suggestions\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Experts need control, not generic suggestions\u0026lt;/h3\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Experts don’t want a cheerful answer. They want:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Assumptions and bounds\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Counterfactuals\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Sensitivity (“if cost rises 3%, what breaks?”)\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;A precise record of “why”\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;This is exactly why human-AI interaction design matters. Amershi et al.’s \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3290605.3300233\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Guidelines for Human-AI Interaction\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; is one of the most usable, practitioner-friendly synthesis of what these systems must do: make status visible, set expectations, support efficient correction and plan for when the system is wrong.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h3 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;mixed-teams-need-progressive-autonomy\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Mixed teams need progressive autonomy\u0026lt;/h3\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The same decision can — and should — run in different modes depending on role and risk:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;A novice gets guided assistive flows\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;An operator gets constrained recommendations with quick correction\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;An SME gets full control, diagnostics and policy authoring\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;This is how you scale decision quality without asking everyone to become a data scientist.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;step-4-use-urgency-correctly-reduce-ambiguity-dont-add-theater\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Step 4: Use urgency correctly — reduce ambiguity, don’t add theater\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Business urgency is the other major variable, and most teams get it backwards.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;When urgency is high, organizations don’t just need speed. They need clarity:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Fewer meetings\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Fewer debates\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Fewer conflicting spreadsheets\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Fewer “depends”\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;A weak copilot often increases ambiguity under pressure — because it introduces another opinion without accountability.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h3 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;urgency-changes-the-goal\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Urgency changes the goal\u0026lt;/h3\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;When urgency is low, optimize for trust-building and learning:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Instrument decisions and outcomes\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Capture exceptions\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Build the SME policy layer\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Prove lift vs. baseline\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;When urgency is high, optimize for speed with safety:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Automate reversible steps\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Require approvals for irreversible actions\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Escalate anomalies aggressively\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Make rollback a product feature, not an ops scramble\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;This is why I’m allergic to “agentic” as a vague aspiration. Under pressure, autonomous theater is worse than manual discipline. The right move is often guarded autonomy — small reversible actions, tight bounds, aggressive escalation.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;step-5-the-mode-selector-that-holds-up-across-industries\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Step 5: The mode selector that holds up across industries\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;If you want a rule that works across domains, use DPOM’s mode selector:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Risk × Frequency × Reversibility\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;High risk + low reversibility → Manual or Assistive\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Medium risk + reversible actions → Assistive + approvals + automation hooks\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Low risk + high frequency + reversible → Guarded agentic → Agentic\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;This avoids the two expensive failure modes:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ol start=\u0026quot;1\u0026quot; class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Shipping “agents” that require constant babysitting\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Staying manual while competitors compound speed\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ol\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;the-autonomy-ladder-how-decision-products-should-evolve\u0026quot;\u0026gt;The autonomy ladder: How decision products should evolve\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The path that consistently works is progressive autonomy:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ol start=\u0026quot;1\u0026quot; class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Observe (Instrumented manual+).\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; Capture decisions, outcomes, context. Build the decision dataset.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Recommend (Assistive).\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; Provide options and trade-offs. Improve consistency. Make correction effortless.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Constrain (Guarded agentic).\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; Execute within SME-defined policy. Escalate anything outside bounds.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Delegate (Agentic).\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; Automate routine decisions; humans manage exceptions and evolve policy.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ol\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The key is that autonomy is earned, not declared.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;And the target isn’t “trust” as a vibe. It’s appropriate reliance — users follow the system when it’s right and override it when it’s wrong. That distinction is central to the classic work by Lee \u0026amp;amp; See on \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1518/hfes.46.1.50_30392\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;designing automation, so reliance matches capability\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;a-real-world-pattern-ive-seen-repeatedly\u0026quot;\u0026gt;A real-world pattern I’ve seen repeatedly\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;In every high-stakes domain I’ve worked in — security, risk, supply chain and product development — the inflection point wasn’t a better model. It was turning SME judgment into an executable policy layer.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;One common scenario: a team ships “assistive AI” that generates recommendations quickly, but outcomes remain inconsistent because the real rules live in three senior people’s heads. The fix is almost never “prompt harder.” It’s:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Capture constraints, escalation triggers and exception playbooks\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Instrument reversals (when humans override the system)\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Treat those reversals as the learning signal\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Only then automate small, reversible actions under tight bounds\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;That’s when the system stops behaving like a suggestion engine and starts behaving like a decision product: fewer meetings, faster decisions and a measurable reduction in exceptions that require senior review.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;dpom-toolkit-what-i-implement-in-practice\u0026quot;\u0026gt;DPOM toolkit: What I implement in practice\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;If you want to operationalize DPOM, start with three artifacts and three metrics:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Artifacts\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Mode selector worksheet:\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; Risk × Frequency × Reversibility per decision\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;SME policy layer template:\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; constraints, thresholds, escalations, exceptions, acceptance tests, rollback\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Autonomy ladder criteria:\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; explicit gates for moving Observe → Recommend → Constrain → Delegate\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Metrics (the executive scoreboard)\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ol start=\u0026quot;1\u0026quot; class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Time-to-decision (median + P90)\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Exception rate (% escalated to SMEs)\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Reversal rate (% overridden by humans after recommendation/action)\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ol\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Reversal rate is especially powerful because it converts “human disagreement” from politics into a measurable signal the product can learn from.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;the-question-that-reveals-where-to-start\u0026quot;\u0026gt;The question that reveals where to start\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;If you’re leading AI product strategy in a non-tech industry, here’s the most diagnostic question I know:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;What is the highest-frequency decision in your business that still depends on a handful of experts — and what would it take to make it safe, consistent and scalable?\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;That’s where decision products create compounding advantage.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;And it’s how you move from “we added AI” to “we changed the operating system of the business.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; de más de dos décadas en sectores donde una hora de caída puede costar cientos de miles de euros sin mencionar temas reputacionales, he aprendido que cuando, como CIO, subes a presentar, justificar y defender una inversión ante un comité, hay un lenguaje que funciona y otro que no. “Hemos ahorrado horas de trabajo” no funciona. “Hemos reducido un 35% la probabilidad de que este proceso crítico nos cueste dinero” sí funciona. La diferencia es la que hay entre un proyecto que sobrevive y uno que se cancela en la siguiente revisión de presupuesto.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;el-unico-numero-que-importa-cuanto-cuesta-el-impacto-de-fallos\u0026quot;\u0026gt;El único número que importa: cuánto cuesta el impacto de fallos\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;La forma más directa de justificar agentes en términos financieros es algo que cualquier director financiero entiende sin traducción técnica: \u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;cuánto dinero pierdes cuando algo se rompe o sufres un problema grave\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;. Probabilidad de que ocurra un problema grave, multiplicada por lo que cuesta cada hora que ese problema está activo — dinero que pierdes, multas que pagas, clientes que se van —, multiplicada por cuánto tardan en arreglarlo.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;La mayoría de inversiones en agentes justificadas solo con productividad se ciñen a una parte menor del problema: el tiempo que dedicamos a tareas repetitivas. Lo que mueve la aguja es un agente que acorta cuánto dura un incidente porque lo detecta antes —hay datos contrastados de reducciones del 25 al 40% en tiempos de detección y resolución—. Lo que mueve la aguja es un agente que reduce la probabilidad de que un problema llegue a producirse. Y lo que mueve la aguja es un agente que limita el daño: corta el problema antes de que se extienda, activa protecciones automáticas, reduce hasta dónde llega el impacto.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;No prometo cero incidentes. \u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Lo que defiendo es medir y reducir lo que cuesta cada problema de forma sistemática, trimestre a trimestre\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;. Eso ayuda a modelar la inteligencia artificial hacia un programa de mejora continua con resultados que se acumulan y se van midiendo.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h3 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;ejemplo\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Ejemplo:\u0026lt;/h3\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Una entidad financiera europea con 500.000 clientes sufría caídas en su sistema de pagos una vez al trimestre. \u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Coste medio: 150.000 euros por hora (negocio parado + penalizaciones regulatorias). \u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Tiempo de detección: 45 minutos. Tiempo de resolución: 3,5 horas. \u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Coste por incidente: 600.000 euros. \u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Coste anual: 2,4 millones de euros.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;La entidad implementó un agente de detección de anomalías enfocado exclusivamente en métricas de latencia y tasas de error. \u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Inversión inicial: 180.000 euros. \u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Coste operativo anual: 60.000 euros.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Resultado tras 12 meses: \u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Detección de 45 min a 8 min\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Resolución de 3,5h a 1,8h\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Coste medio por incidente: de 600.000 a 280.000 euros. \u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Reducción anual: 1,28 millones de euros. \u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;ROI del primer año: 433%.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Creo que es importante medir primero los incidentes actuales que sufres ahora, cuánto tardas en detectarlos, cuánto tardas en resolverlos y qué te cuesta cada hora. Calcular la mejora que esperas con el agente. Sumar el coste real de hacerlo funcionar: servidores, guardar los registros el tiempo que exige regulación, usuarios y permisos, y el equipo que lo controla y supervisa. Si los números no cuadran antes de empezar, el caso no se sostiene y es menos defendible.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;la-paradoja-de-la-productividad-que-nadie-mide\u0026quot;\u0026gt;La paradoja de la productividad que nadie mide\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Hay un coste oculto que casi ningún piloto o POC (prueba de concepto) mide: la intensificación del trabajo. Un estudio reciente de ocho meses en una empresa tecnológica estadounidense documentó que los empleados que adoptaron IA generativa no trabajaron menos: trabajaron más. Las tareas se extendieron (“si puedo hacerlo con IA, ¿por qué no lo intento?”), las fronteras entre trabajo y descanso se difuminaron (un \u0026lt;em\u0026gt;prompt \u0026lt;/em\u0026gt;rápido durante el almuerzo), y el \u0026lt;em\u0026gt;multitasking \u0026lt;/em\u0026gt;se multiplicó (varios agentes corriendo en paralelo).\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;El resultado: mayor volumen de trabajo sin tiempo recuperado. Como resumió un ingeniero del estudio: “Pensabas que con IA trabajarías menos. Pero realmente no trabajas menos. Trabajas lo mismo o incluso más”. \u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Para un comité de dirección, esto importa porque invalida el argumento clásico de “ahorras X horas al mes por empleado”. Si esas horas se reinvierten inmediatamente en más tareas —sin descanso, sin reflexión, sin margen—, no estás ganando productividad sostenible. Estás acumulando deuda cognitiva que se paga con errores, \u0026lt;em\u0026gt;burnout\u0026lt;/em\u0026gt; y decisiones apresuradas justo cuando más necesitas que la gente piense con claridad.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;por-que-son-mas-efectivos-los-agentes-especializados\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Por qué son más efectivos los agentes especializados\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Voy a defender una idea que igual no es compartida: los agentes diseñados para hacer una tarea especializada y hacerla bien tienen tasas de éxito muy superiores a los generalistas. Al menos hoy en día.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“Especializado” no significa simple. Significa que el agente tiene un trabajo definido, unas reglas claras, unos controles reales y una forma objetiva de saber si lo está haciendo bien o mal. Gartner predice que más del 40% de los proyectos con agentes se cancelarán antes de 2027 por costes que se disparan o por falta de controles adecuados. Sin hablar de los datos… y la calidad de los mismos. La diferencia entre los que sobreviven y los que no casi nunca lo hacen es tecnológica y creo más asociable la disciplina operativa y sobre todo ESTRATÉGICA.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Los agentes especializados pueden validar con situaciones acotadas antes de escribir código. Se pueden revisar y auditar porque cada acción queda registrada. Pueden contener el impacto y pasear porque el daño máximo que pueden causar está limitado por diseño. Se puede gobernar porque hay reglas claras. Y se pueden mejorar porque trabajan contra objetivos estables con KPI claros y bien definidos.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Los agentes de propósito siguen un patrón predecible: alguien pide “una cosa más”, la definición de éxito se vuelve borrosa, el agente necesita acceder a más datos, y el coste crece más deprisa que el valor. Estudios recientes recientes indican que los sistemas que hacen uso de agentes pueden consumir hasta cinco veces más capacidad de cálculo por tarea que una implementación estándar. No es un dato teórico, es una factura real a final de mes.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;em\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Red Flag\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/em\u0026gt;: si no puedes definir y delimitar qué datos lee el agente, qué puede hacer, cómo saber si lo hizo bien y cómo deshacerlo si falla, no es candidato para producción.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;donde-se-esfuman-los-presupuestos\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Dónde se esfuman los presupuestos\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Cuando se cancela un proyecto de agentes, casi nunca es porque la tecnología no haya funcionado. Es porque se han dejado cinco partidas de gastos sin predecir:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Calidad de los datos\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;. Si la información es incompleta o contradictoria, el agente no se para. Produce resultados que parecen correctos pero no lo son. En procesos críticos, una respuesta convincente pero equivocada no es un fallo técnico: es un riesgo de negocio. En 2024, un tribunal de Columbia Británica dictaminó que una importante aerolínea internacional era responsable por información incorrecta proporcionada por su chatbot. Solo un tercio de las organizaciones tiene mecanismos para prevenir este tipo de errores. La adopción es cada vez mayor pero también este tipo de acciones lo será.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Identidad y permisos\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;. Cada agente necesita de una identidad propia, permisos mínimos y registro completo. Solo el 10% de las organizaciones gestiona bien la identidad de sus sistemas automatizados.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Registro y trazabilidad\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;. Qué hizo el agente, con qué autorización, a partir de qué información. Esto ocupa espacio, hay que guardarlo durante años y necesita control de acceso.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Aislamiento\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;. Si un agente toca sistemas críticos, necesita funcionar en un entorno controlado. Investigadores han documentado vulnerabilidades que permiten robar información sin que nadie se entere.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Operación del día a día\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;. Investigaciones recientes muestran que en organizaciones que escalan IA, una parte importante del equipo técnico acaba dedicado a tareas relacionadas con el propio mantenimiento de la IA. La operación no tiene un coste menor. Es el principal coste.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;La mayoría de directivos en estudios recientes reconoce que los costes de poner agentes a funcionar superan con mucho lo esperado. El coste existe de todas formas. La decisión es si lo metes en el presupuesto desde el principio, con visibilidad, o si lo pagas después como deuda acumulada.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;cinco-dias-para-saber-si-un-piloto-merece-vivir-o-morir-en-el-intento\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Cinco días para saber si un piloto merece vivir o morir en el intento\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;He desarrollado una prueba que usó antes de meter recursos reales. No sirve para demostrar que un agente “es capaz”. Sirve para saber si el caso de uso se puede operar en el mundo real.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Día 1.- Definir OKR claros. Problema concreto y verificable. Qué datos puede usar. Qué acciones puede realizar. Y cuándo se para si algo va mal. Si no puedes definir cuándo parar, no estás listo para empezar.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Día 2.- Comprobar el entorno. Calidad real de los datos (no la teórica, sino la que hay un lunes por la mañana). Accesos con permisos mínimos. Requisitos de registro definidos.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Día 3.- Modelo MVP. Pocas fuentes, pocas acciones, mucho control. Si para funcionar hace falta “una fuente más” o “un permiso adicional”, eso se apunta como gasto extra.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Día 4.- Medir sin compasión. Cuántas veces interviene una persona. Cuántas veces falla. Cuánto tarda. Si se salta reglas. Si no se puede medir…\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Día 5.- Decisión. Valor conservador. Coste real incluyendo datos, controles y operación. Decisión limpia: adelante, fuera o reducir alcance. Sin zonas grises.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;para-finalizar\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Para finalizar\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;La productividad personal es un beneficio posible. Pero no aguanta un caso de inversión cuando metes los controles que exige una empresa seria. La inversión que sí aguanta es la que reduce lo que te cuesta cuando algo falla y mejora tu capacidad de respuesta y, sobre todo, las posibilidades de anticiparse a problemas o predecirlos. Con pruebas, con límites claros y con capacidad real de recuperación.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;La pregunta que hemos de hacernos no es si nuestra empresa está usando agentes de inteligencia artificial. A estas alturas, prácticamente todas dicen que sí. La pregunta es si los que están funcionando podrían aguantar una auditoría seria mañana por la mañana. Si la respuesta no es un sí rotundo, la organización no tiene un programa de agentes. Tiene una colección de pilotos esperando a convertirse en algo incuestionable y, lo peor, nada controlable.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;En la entrega final cerraremos el círculo con el \u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;papel del CIO\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;: cómo diseñar supervisión que funcione a escala, con métricas, gobierno y arquitectura operativa para tener más agentes sin perder el control. Porque escalar no es desplegar más agentes. Escalar es gobernar bien los que ya tienes antes de añadir el siguiente.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u003cspan col-6@lg col-start-3@lg\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;article-column__content\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;section class=\u0026quot;wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;container\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/section\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Executives at hardware and lumber retailer Do It Best didn’t want innovation to take a back seat to the extensive work needed to integrate two IT systems after the company acquired competitor True Value in late 2024.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;A year after the acquisition, the company announced a new \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.doitbestonline.com/2025/do-it-best-and-true-value-power-technology-expansion/\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;innovation hub\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; in Dallas focused on AI and other emerging technologies, and it officially opened in January.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The tech hub will push Do It Best’s IT mission forward by concentrating on data, intelligence, and ease of use, says \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.doitbestonline.com/about-us/leadership-team/ken-widner/\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Ken Widner\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;, the company’s executive vice president and CIO. The company plans to hire about \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.doitbestcareers.com/openings/\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;25 IT professionals for the center\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;, including data scientists, software developers, and user experience experts.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“With the acquisition of True Value, we have to be able to focus on merging systems and figuring out what the combined infrastructure is going to look like from a technology perspective,” he says. “But at the same time, we can’t lose sight of our members and dealers and technology that they need to be successful and run their stores.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;With technology advancing at a rapid pace, executives realized that incremental changes to existing Do It Best IT resources weren’t going to be enough to push innovation forward as the company simultaneously pulled in True Value’s IT systems, Widner says.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;One top priority for the innovation hub will be to build AI tools to help stores better serve customers, he adds. “Everyone’s talking about AI, and we know it’s a game changer for our industry,” he says. “We can’t just take our foot off the gas when it comes to new technology and strategy just to work on integration stuff.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;predicting-store-needs\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Predicting store needs\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;One AI project will focus on predicting inventory needs at Do It Best and True Value stores around the US, so that, for example, stores in areas facing unexpected winter storms have enough shovels and ice melt pellets in stock.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The company is also using AI to map product SKU codes at Do It Best and True Value to look for overlap between the two chains, Widner says.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The hub will also help stores make data-backed decisions, using \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/228901/what-is-predictive-analytics-transforming-data-into-future-insights.html\u0026quot;\u0026gt;predictive analytics\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;, to decide what products to carry, based on factors like the age of the homes in the surrounding area. For example, a store in an area with a lot of housing built in the 1950s might carry more roofing supplies than a store in an area with homes built in the past 10 years.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“The hub is helping our members decide what products they should carry and when it comes to how they’re performing and how they compare to their peers in the same marketplaces,” Widner says. “We can provide technology now and help provide them data to be able to make better decisions, to really grow top-line sales and then ultimately provide products and services that we know the consumer wants.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;gearing-up\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Gearing up\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;While Widner has high hopes for the innovation hub, the project did present challenges, mostly related to recruiting and onboarding new employees, he says. As the company hired, it realized the need to tweak some of its onboarding process.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“When you’re talking about hiring the number of engineers that we’re hiring, getting them up to speed and being productive was something that we wanted to focus on ahead of time,” he says. “We had a lot of our technical leads and senior engineers really dive into what our onboarding process looked like and how we could optimize it, updating our documentation and putting it in locations where people can get access to it.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The new location also created support challenges, and Do It Best needed to pay special attention to ensure that the new IT team in Dallas had access to laptops and other essential equipment.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“Some of the challenges actually were more on the operational side around making sure that the facility was ready,” Widner says. “The badge reader was in place. We had a refrigerator, a microwave, keyboards and mice and stuff on people’s desks, whiteboards in place. Those were some of the things that we were rushing around and finishing up at the last minute.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;integration-still-important\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Integration still important\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Meanwhile, the company has continued to integrate IT teams and systems between Do It Best and True Value after the acquisition doubled the company’s number of stores to about 9,000.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Widner’s team has looked for best-of-breed IT solutions at both companies, instead of requiring True Value stores and facilities to adopt Do It Best technologies. The IT team took about a year to evaluate the tech stacks at the two merging companies.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“We really wanted to be strategic on our approach and not come in with an assumption that we’re just going to lift and shift True Value systems onto the Do It Best system,” he adds. “We really wanted to look at things that we think we do well on the Do It Best side and the things that True Value did well on their side, and how do we get to a best of breed?”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The Do It Best approach to innovation and integration seems to be a thoughtful one, says one outside expert. An innovation hub, or \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/194085/ai-center-of-excellence-a-new-engine-for-driving-business-transformation.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;center of excellence\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;, is a good idea, especially for AI when there are so many ways to fail when adopting the technology, says \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://my.idc.com/getdoc.jsp?containerId=PRF003977\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Ashish Nadkarni\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;, group vice president and general manager for worldwide infrastructure research at IT analyst firm IDC.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;With most enterprise IT teams focused on day-to-day operational needs, an innovation hub can give IT leaders time to think strategically about AI adoption, he says.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“Even in the best of best IT organizations, the focus is on just running the thing,” Nadkarni says. “They’re focused on making sure that the bread-and-butter business of the company is not interrupted by any incidents. A lot of times, people don’t have the cycles, the bandwidth, to take a step back and think about the big picture.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The True Value acquisition can add complexity to the way the combined company thinks about AI, and an innovation hub can help bring the two companies’ ideas together, he adds.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“Every company’s AI implementation is going to look different,” Nadkarni says. “When the two companies are brought together, their AI initiatives might not even look like each other, and you can’t just take the two together and put them in one place. You have to really think through it.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan id=\u0026quot;remove_no_follow\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;grid grid--cols-10@md grid--cols-8@lg article-column\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;col-12 col-10@md col-6@lg col-start-3@lg\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;article-column__content\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;section class=\u0026quot;wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;container\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/section\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;As generative AI moves from experimentation into day-to-day operations, many technology leaders are reaching the conclusion that a powerful model by itself does not offer sufficient long-term differentiation. \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.gartner.com/en/newsroom/press-releases/2023-10-03-gartner-poll-finds-55-percent-of-organizations-are-in-piloting-or-production-mode-with-generative-ai\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Gartner reports\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; that more than half of organizations are already piloting or running generative AI in production, a shift that has pushed CIOs beyond questions of raw capability and toward a more practical concern: \u0026lt;em\u0026gt;Why do some AI initiatives create lasting value while others stall after a promising pilot\u0026lt;/em\u0026gt;?\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;That does not mean great models aren’t critically important or disruptive. It does mean that model capabilities alone are not sufficiently transformative for the business.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;As foundation models become more capable and widely available, the advantage shifts away from intelligence in the abstract and toward how effectively AI is integrated inside the organization.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The companies seeing real impact tend to make deliberate choices about \u0026lt;em\u0026gt;what\u0026lt;/em\u0026gt; their AI understands, \u0026lt;em\u0026gt;how\u0026lt;/em\u0026gt; it shows up in everyday work and \u0026lt;em\u0026gt;where\u0026lt;/em\u0026gt; it gets adopted. Those decisions—more than the choice of model itself—are what determine whether AI creates lasting, proprietary differentiation.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Does your AI actually understand your business?\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Many AI discussions still start with capability. Effective CIOs find it is more productive to start with context.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;AI systems can generate fluent answers, but without visibility into where data comes from, how current it is or whether it is reliable, those answers quickly lose value. The failure mode is rarely apparent by the time bad data gets to the model. Rather than errors being thrown, the system often produces \u0026lt;em\u0026gt;confidently incorrect\u0026lt;/em\u0026gt; responses based on stale or incomplete information.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Data provides the context that makes AI work – or not. Foundational models are trained on massive corpuses from the outside world and the internet. Still, they can become easily confused when faced with a company’s internal world of private data, including proprietary concepts and alien terminology.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Most organizations already have orchestration in place, generating up-to-date, accurate context as a byproduct. Over time, the operational metadata from orchestration becomes a record of how the business actually runs. For example, when a new table becomes the preferred system of record, or a business rule is changed, the orchestration layer and the systems it operates are configured to make it so. This new knowledge can be inferred by this layer to update the company’s AI context quickly and automatically.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;When AI is grounded in that reality, it behaves differently. It avoids deprecated sources, surfaces data health issues and produces outputs that are easier to trust. As model capabilities converge, this context layer is becoming one of the clearest sources of differentiation.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;a\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;How it shows up in real work\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;A model by itself is infrastructure. What employees experience is everything wrapped around it.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;AI tools that gain traction tend to appear in the flow of work rather than pulling users into new destinations. They offer help at the right moment, explain what they are doing and give people clear control over what gets accepted or rejected.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Trust comes from design choices that may seem mundane but matter in practice. Audit trails, feedback loops and clear escalation paths all play a role. Without them, even capable systems struggle to build enough trust to move beyond experimentation. This is consistent with \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.forrester.com/blogs/trust-alignment-and-adaptivity-must-be-the-focus-of-your-ai-initiatives/)\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Forrester’s argument that sustainable AI hinges on trust\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; (and the operating behaviors that create it).\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The same model can feel either experimental or essential depending on how thoughtfully the experience is designed.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Where adoption really happens\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Distribution is often framed as a go-to-market concern. For enterprise AI, it is more of an adoption challenge.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;AI spreads fastest when it meets people where they already work. Email, messaging tools, terminals, development environments and core business systems all act as natural surfaces. When AI appears as a new collaborator inside familiar tools, adoption comes naturally and feels like a welcome addition.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;This shift boosts productivity precisely because it avoids forcing behavioral change, which often becomes an obstacle in its own right. Employees are not being asked to learn a new system. They are interacting with a new capability inside workflows they already trust. Over time, broad usage also produces strong signals about what works best, allowing teams to refine AI systems based on real demand rather than assumptions.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;For many organizations, lasting value comes not from individual deployments but from becoming part of the default way work gets done.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;a\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;Where the real edge comes from\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Models remain a critical source of capability and differentiation, but they do not deliver value in a vacuum. Their impact depends on how well they are connected to context, wrapped in usable experiences and distributed across real workflows.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;CIOs are also seeing new forms of model differentiation emerge around speed and specialization. In many use cases, smaller models fine-tuned on proprietary data and deployed close to the workflow outperform larger general-purpose models. They respond faster, cost less to operate and align more closely with specific tasks.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Proprietary data is central to this shift. Without it, AI outputs are largely interchangeable. Organizations are increasingly recognizing that their internal metadata represents a significant source of advantage to make sense of their business data, and that fine-tuning and domain adaptation are practical ways to turn that data into something defensible.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Just as importantly, these systems need a governance posture that keeps them reliable as they scale — i.e., clarity on responsibilities, traceability and mechanisms to manage risk as usage expands. That’s the core focus of \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;NIST’s AI Risk Management Framework\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;, which is designed to help organizations incorporate “trustworthiness considerations” into the design, development and use of AI systems.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot;\u0026gt;What this means for CIOs\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;For CIOs, the challenge is no longer whether AI works. It’s how to create an advantage tailored to their organization.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Organizations seeing sustained impact tend to focus less on individual AI tools and more on integration with the systems around them. Context, experience, distribution and specialization determine whether AI becomes a short-term productivity boost or a durable part of how the business operates.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; col-6@lg col-start-3@lg\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;article-column__content\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;section class=\u0026quot;wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;container\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/section\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Technology decisions aren’t immune to the macroeconomic context in which the companies making them must operate. So politics, emerging threats, and regulations will shape the agenda of IT directors this year.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;And among the trends that Gartner has identified as shaping the technology agenda throughout 2026 is geopatriation, defined as the relocation of workloads from a cloud hosting environment — typically a hyperscale public cloud — that’s perceived to pose heightened geopolitical risks, to an alternative storage environment that offers greater sovereignty.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Storage migrates to sovereign clouds or even \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/4101918/cios-shift-from-cloud-first-to-cloud-smart.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;on-prem data centers\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; in an attempt to mitigate risks and potential problems. But given so many uncertainties, it’s arguable data is being repatriated.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Gartner concludes this is not only based on its general market observations, but also by directly gauging the concerns of company executives. During the first half of 2025, it recorded a 305% increase in requests for information on how to mitigate the potential exposure of using global suppliers, and that by 2030, 75% of European and Middle Eastern companies will have geopatriated their virtual cargo, compared to 5% in 2025.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;the-golden-age-of-the-sovereign-cloud\u0026quot;\u0026gt;The golden age of the sovereign cloud\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Ultimately, this trend is another facet of \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/4038164/why-cios-need-to-respond-to-digital-sovereignty-now.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;the sovereign cloud boom\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;. The growth of cloud sovereignty has been exponential over the past year, says Alfons Buxó, global engineering leader at Deloitte. The push for it, he says, is to seek greater digital autonomy and protect community interests, while developing a critical industry.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The key to understanding a sovereign cloud, adds Google Cloud Spain’s national technology director Héctor Sánchez Montenegro, is that it’s not a one-size-fits-all concept. “Depending on the location, sector, or regulatory context, sovereignty has a different meaning for each customer,” he says. Google already offers sovereign clouds, whose guarantee of sovereignty isn’t based on a single product, but on a strategy that separates the technology from the operations. “We understand that sovereignty isn’t binary, but rather a spectrum of needs we guarantee through three levels of isolation and control,” he adds.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Buxó also says sovereignty is a continuous spectrum, not a digital function. In the case of the EU, he says, concepts such as applicable regulations, operational autonomy, asset ownership, and technology stacks are considered, so every company and situation require a unique approach. “Organizations will have to reassess their digital strategies in order to understand and decide on the best option for each case. We’ll continue with private, public, and sovereign clouds,” Buxó says.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;the-challenges-of-the-context\u0026quot;\u0026gt;The challenges of the context\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;One of the certainties of this sovereign cloud boom is it’s closely connected to the context in which organizations, companies, and other cloud end users operate.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;While digital sovereignty was less prevalent at the beginning of the century, it’s now become ubiquitous, especially as political decisions in various countries have solidified technology as a key geostrategic asset.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“Data sovereignty is a fundamental part of digital sovereignty, to the point that in practice, it’s becoming a requirement for employment contracts,” says María Loza Correa, professor of the master’s program in cybersecurity at the International University of La Rioja in Spain. “Current geopolitical instability, coupled with dependence on digital infrastructures belonging to certain hyperscalers worldwide and the European legal framework, has led to an emphasis on the pursuit of digital sovereignty, as it’s a necessary condition for political and economic sovereignty.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Recent European regulatory developments are already moving in this direction, as is the case with the \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://digital-strategy.ec.europa.eu/en/policies/cybersecurity-strategy\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;European Cybersecurity Strategy\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;, which addresses resilience and technological sovereignty. Europe wants to break from external dependence, where information can pass through its own infrastructure.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;But it’s not just a question of who owns the infrastructure or the solutions. It’s also what happens when the landscape becomes volatile and uncertain due to, for example, pandemics, war, and geopolitical tensions. In the wake of instability, nobody wants their tech to become collateral damage.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“In the current context, the EU, Canada, and other countries have become aware of their digital dependencies on third parties,” Buxó adds. “Sovereign cloud computing is a consequence of this realization and impacts not only critical sectors like defense and national security, but it’s also becoming a relevant issue for other heavily regulated sectors like banking, pharmaceuticals, and healthcare.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;With the technological landscape becoming more unsure and complex, the goal is to know and mitigate risks where possible, and create additional options. “We’re at a crucial moment,” Loza Correa points out. “Data is a key business asset that must be protected.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Added to this is the \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/4121122/cios-must-reclaim-agency-over-our-ai-future.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;AI boom\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;, which is driving more companies and public bodies to the cloud. “As organizations accelerate their digital transformation to harness the economic potential of AI, they specifically need robust digital sovereignty controls,” says Sánchez Montenegro. With greater sovereignty and control over what happens to information, the doors of AI open even to the most sensitive sectors using highly protected information.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The move to a sovereign cloud isn’t a defensive retreat, but a strategic modernization, he adds, driven more by resilience than regulatory pressure or concerns about the impact of geopolitics on IT infrastructure.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;a-break-in-the-cloud\u0026quot;\u0026gt;A break in the cloud\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Gartner’s analysis of increasing geopatriation warns that many organizations are realizing that local alternatives can be unappealing and disruptive. Local cloud providers, however, see this scenario as a potential windfall. For global hyperscalers, though, the market trend is driving them to accelerate sovereignty options to reassure customers and avoid losing market share.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;If three out of four European companies repatriate their data workloads, however, will it become necessary to have on-prem infrastructure? Gartner says that most sovereign cloud spending will come primarily from new digital solutions or legacy workloads expected to be migrated to a cloud environment, says Rene Buest, the consulting firm’s senior director analyst. “Local cloud providers will benefit from this,” he says.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The question, therefore, is how the cloud market will be reorganized seeing that hyperscalers have already developed sovereign clouds of different types and approaches. “We’ve moved to a phase of control over data, which involves geographical considerations and applicable regulations, rather than scalability and efficiency,” says Loza Correa.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Europe has already launched frameworks such as the \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://commission.europa.eu/document/download/09579818-64a6-4dd5-9577-446ab6219113_en\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Cloud Sovereignty Framework\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; and announced future investments in gigafactories and other infrastructure. So this is a marathon that requires ambitious commitment. “To fully realize the economic value of AI, Europe needs to triple its data center capacity in the next five to seven years, a task that’ll require an estimated investment of €400 billion in digital infrastructure,” says Sánchez Montenegro.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan 텍스트, 이미지, 오디오, 비디오를 통합적으로 처리하는 멀티모달 음·영상 공동 생성 아키텍처를 기반으로 개발됐다. 기존 1.5 버전 대비 생성 품질과 제어 기능이 개선됐으며, 특히 복합 장면과 상호작용이 많은 영상 환경에서의 안정성 향상에 초점을 맞췄다.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;바이트댄스 \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://seed.bytedance.com/en/blog/seedance-2-0-%E6%AD%A3%E5%BC%8F%E5%8F%91%E5%B8%83\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;공식 블로그에 따르면\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;, 씨댄스 2.0은 복잡한 움직임이나 다수 인물이 등장하는 장면에서 비교적 안정적인 결과물을 생성하는 데 중점을 두고 있다. 인물 간 상호작용, 빠른 동작 전환, 카메라 이동이 포함된 장면에서도 물리적 일관성을 유지하려는 설계가 적용됐다. 예를 들어 스포츠 경기나 군무, 액션 장면 등 고난도 동작이 포함된 장면에서 동작의 연결성과 균형을 보다 자연스럽게 구현하는 데 개선이 이루어졌다.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;멀티모달 입력 범위도 확대됐다. 사용자는 최대 이미지 9개, 영상 3개, 오디오 클립 3개와 텍스트 지시문을 조합해 입력할 수 있다. 모델은 이 자료들을 종합적으로 분석해 구도, 동작, 분위기, 음향 특성 등을 참고한 새로운 영상을 생성한다. 바이트댄스는 “이 기능이 기존 단일 텍스트·이미지 입력 방식 대비 창작 자유도를 높여줄 것”이라고 설명했다.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;영상 제어 기능도 보완됐다. 비교적 긴 스크립트나 세부 동작 지시가 포함된 요청에 대해 지시문 반영 정확도가 향상됐으며, 생성 이후 특정 장면이나 인물, 동작을 수정하는 편집 기능이 추가됐다. 또한 기존 영상에 이어지는 장면을 생성하는 ‘영상 연장’ 기능도 지원한다. 이를 통해 하나의 결과물을 반복적으로 보완하거나 확장하는 작업이 가능해졌다.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;오디오 기능 역시 업데이트됐다. 씨댄스 2.0은 듀얼 채널 스테레오 음향을 지원하며, 배경음, 효과음, 대사 등을 영상과 동기화해 출력할 수 있다. 빗소리, 마찰음, 발걸음 소리 등 세부적인 음향 표현에서 정밀도를 높이려는 개선이 반영됐다. 특히 음성과 화면 간 타이밍 정합성을 강화해 시청 경험의 일관성을 높이는 데 초점을 맞췄다.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;적용 분야는 광고, 영상 콘텐츠 제작, 게임 애니메이션, 전자상거래 영상 등 다양한 영역을 포함한다. 최대 15초 분량의 멀티샷 영상과 음향을 함께 생성할 수 있도록 설계됐으며, 전문 제작 환경에서의 활용 가능성을 염두에 두고 기능이 구성됐다. jihyun.lee@foundryco.com\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\u0026quot;wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;container\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/section\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;이번에 공개된 재판지원 AI는 대법원 판례 및 판결문, 법령 및 대법원규칙, 결정례와 유권해석, 판사와 법원 직원들이 참고하는 실무 안내서(실무제요)와 법령 해설서(주석서) 등 다양한 사법 자료를 활용한다. 단순한 키워드 검색을 넘어 사용자의 질의 취지를 분석해 관련 법률 쟁점과 자료를 찾아 정리해 제시하는 방식이다. 또한 답변과 함께 관련 판례와 법령 등 참고자료를 제공해 이용자가 원문을 확인할 수 있도록 했다.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;해당 재판지원 AI는 외부의 거대 언어모델(LLM)이나 공개형 AI 서비스에 의존하지 않고, 법원 내부 인프라를 기반으로 한 자체 AI 플랫폼 위에서 운영된다. 구체적인 기술에 대해 CIO코리아가 문의했으나, 법원으로부터 별도의 답변을 받지 못했다. 다만 법원은 \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.scourt.go.kr/portal/news/NewsViewAction.work;jsessionid=MnwsjujX7EG6bLz7DY2BDoV2yKfxpCEbHR6uYZn4dqfbezlqtsGkCmZjezHLAIFt.BJEUWS04_servlet_SCWWW?pageIndex=1\u0026amp;amp;searchWord=\u0026amp;amp;searchOption=\u0026amp;amp;gubun=6\u0026amp;amp;seqnum=2934\u0026quot; target=\u0026quot;_blank\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;보도자료를 통해\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; 사법 정보의 특성상 높은 수준의 보안과 기밀 유지가 요구되는 만큼, 내부 시스템을 통해 보안성과 독립성을 확보했다고 설명했다. 아울러 법원 업무의 특수성을 반영한 맞춤형 AI 모델을 개발하고, 단계적으로 성능을 고도화해 나갈 예정이라고 밝혔다.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;법원은 재판지원 AI를 통해 재판 과정에서의 법률 리서치와 참고자료 검토에 소요되는 시간을 단축하고, 다양한 관련 자료를 구조적으로 파악할 수 있을 것으로 기대하고 있다. 방대한 판례와 법령을 일일이 검색하고 비교·검토해야 했던 기존 업무 부담이 일정 부분 경감될 수 있다는 것이다.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;또한 법원은 인공지능 시스템의 특성상 일부 답변에 부정확하거나 미흡한 내용이 포함될 가능성을 배제할 수 없다고 밝혔다. 따라서 최종적인 판단과 책임은 어디까지나 이용자의 검토와 판단에 따른다는 점을 분명히 했다. AI를 ‘보조 수단’으로 활용하되, 재판의 본질적 판단 권한은 인간에게 맡기겠다는 셈이다.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;법원은 이번 시범 운영을 시작으로 사용자 의견을 적극 수렴해 답변 정확도 개선, 근거 제시 체계 고도화, 기능 확장 등을 지속적으로 추진할 계획이다. 향후에는 사건 요지 자동 정리, 쟁점 분석 지원 등 보다 고도화된 기능도 추가 개발해 재판지원 AI를 실질적인 업무 혁신 도구로 발전시킨다는 방침이다.\u0026lt;br\u0026gt;jihyun.lee@foundryco.com\u0026lt;br\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan
